comments.body: this is even more strange
if the tests don't fail then I am puzzled what exactly you are changing here

This test fails (or are you talking about other tests?) when e.g. the nulls_fixtures is used. It will be a float then (float('NaN')). As a 'str' I also iterable (And valid according to the tests), I'm testing for this. Note that as the cast is a no-op at runtime I need to do the check here in order to satisfy our agreement this function always should return a List (Iterable according to the existing tests) 

It was how I could make the existing tests pass, having stronger typing and the new test pass.
Should this be if not `isinstance(result, list)` or should the return type of _pull_field be typed as Iterable?
Iâ€™ll change the return type to `Iterable` (`str` is valid and is not a list)

Should this just be `pd.isnull(result)`? The consequence of this being an isinstance check would be that all scalar values would return nothing right? 

I know there was some conversation around this before but I think should disambiguate between missing values and scalar values; the former is fine whereas the latter should raise a `TypeError`

You have a point. But should the `TypeError` be raised here then to make it more user friendly? Because otherwise the `TypeError` will be raised from 

```
                recs = [
                    nested_to_record(r, sep=sep, max_level=max_level)
                    if isinstance(r, dict)
                    else r
                    for r in recs
                ]
```

Which is not very indicative  of what is wrong and more importantly where. It took me quite some time to find out in my data what went wrong and why as it can just happen in the middle of a 100mb file.
Yea I think can raise a TypeError here if not missing or Dict/List
so I will do a check with `pd.isnull` and will check with `is_scalar`.
Yea I think that would be better
*sigh* `str` is defined as a scalar. I'm not seeing away around to do `is_scalar(result) and not isinstance(result, Iterable)`. Or is there a better way?
`if is_scalar(result) and pd.isnull(result)`?
when `pd_isnull(result) == true` I need to `result = []`. `pd_isnull` doesn't deal with Iterables :-). I have updated the PR with a suggestion.
Can you add a test case that this would hit?

sorry you need an `elif abc.Iterable` i think maybe

The `Iterator` should only capture the generator input
```python
In [1]: from collections.abc import Iterator

In [2]: isinstance([1,2,3], Iterator)
Out[2]: False

In [3]: isinstance({"a":1}, Iterator)
Out[3]: False

In [4]: def gen():
   ...:     yield from [1,2,3]
   ...:

In [5]: isinstance(gen(), Iterator)
Out[5]: True
```

I can also change `Iterator` to `Iterable`, then I do have to move the `dict` check to be before the `Iterable` check. Thats also fine.

sure, the goal is to lock down the acceptable types, generally Iterable/Dictlike are ok, then *anything* else should raise (we may or may not have tests for this part). I think its worth fixing here to the extent you are changing anyhow.

can you add a doc-string here, as well as typing the return value, also new_dict if can be more specific. may want to make some types that can re-use, something like (just ad-hoc maybe totally off)

```
JSON_ELEMENT = Dict[str, Any]
JSON_DICT= Dict[str, Union[JSON_ELEMENT List[JSON_ELEMENT]]]
```

Have added the doc-strings to the functions and altered the types, tried to be clearer. Didn't use the re-usable types you suggested in the end, as I think the types I've changed it too are simple enough. Do say if they aren't though
